articles.title: Three supermassive black holes have been spotted merging into one
articles.summary: Astronomers have found a system of three supermassive black holes, all actively feeding, that appear to be combining into a single system – a rare event that will help elucidate the physics of complex mergers
articles.content:
Astronomers have found a system of three supermassive black holes, all actively feeding, that appear to be combining into a single system – a rare event that will help elucidate the physics of complex mergers

Supermassive black holes occasionally devour or merge with other black holes MARK GARLICK/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Three galaxies with supermassive black holes at their centres appear to be in the process of merging into a single, giant galaxy, a process that astronomers have rarely seen.

To grow to such enormous sizes, astronomers think supermassive black holes must occasionally devour or merge with other massive black holes during collisions between galaxies. This process is difficult to spot, both because these mergers are short-lived compared with the lifetime of the black hole and because the black holes can only be easily seen if they are giving off light from actively feeding on material, which is also rare. As a result, astronomers have only caught around 150 pairs of galactic black holes in the act of merging.

Now, Emma Schwartzman at the US Naval Research Laboratory in Washington DC and her colleagues have found a group of three supermassive black holes, all actively feeding, that appear to be combining into a single system. “The more galaxies involved, the rarer the system gets,” says Schwartzman.

Each of the supermassive black holes is emitting low-frequency radiation in the form of radio waves, which can pass through dust that blocks other light. This allowed Schwartzman and her team to observe them with two radio observatories, the Very Long Baseline Array in Hawaii and the Very Large Array in New Mexico, then rule out that the light was coming from another source, like bright galaxies full of stars.

“What’s really interesting is that all three of these [black holes] emit in the radio regime, which we’ve never seen before,” says Schwartzman. “There’s no guarantee that any [black hole] would emit in the radio regime.”

There are already visible signs that the galaxies have begun interacting with each other, says Isabella Lamperti at the University of Florence, Italy, but they are at a relatively early stage of interaction, given that two of the galaxies are still separated by around 70,000 light years and the third is 300,000 light years away.

But relative to their total lifetime of billions of years, we are witnessing the end of the story. “It’s like catching the final moments of a galaxy-merging soap opera,” says Emma Kun at Ruhr University Bochum in Germany.

Simulating how three active supermassive black holes merge is extremely difficult, she says, but observing this system will allow physicists to better understand what happens in more complex mergers. “This is the first step of finding some physics about the system,” says Kun.

Journal reference Astrophysical Journal Letters DOI: 10.3847/2041-8213/ae2002

articles.personality_title: Astronomers spot three supermassive black holes merging into one
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Supermassive black holes are giant objects found at the centers of galaxies. Sometimes, when galaxies collide, their black holes can come together and merge. However, seeing this happen is very rare because these events don’t last long and the black holes are hard to detect unless they are actively pulling in material and giving off light.

**What happened** – A team of scientists led by Emma Schwartzman discovered three supermassive black holes in three different galaxies that are merging into one system. All three black holes are actively feeding and emitting radio waves, which helped the astronomers observe them clearly using special radio telescopes in Hawaii and New Mexico.

**Impact** – This is the first time scientists have seen three supermassive black holes merging at once, and all of them emitting radio signals. Watching this rare event helps scientists learn more about how galaxies grow and how black holes interact during these complex mergers. It also gives clues about the final stages of galaxy collisions, which happen over billions of years.

**What's next step** – Researchers will continue studying this system to understand the physics behind these mergers better. They hope to use these observations to improve computer models that simulate how multiple black holes come together and affect their galaxies.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists have observed a rare event where three supermassive black holes are merging, offering new insights into the growth of galaxies and black hole behavior.
articles.personality_title_fr: Trois trous noirs supermassifs en train de fusionner observés par des astronomes
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les trous noirs supermassifs sont d’énormes objets situés au centre des galaxies. Parfois, lorsque les galaxies entrent en collision, leurs trous noirs peuvent se rapprocher et fusionner. Mais il est très rare de voir cela car ces événements sont courts et les trous noirs sont difficiles à détecter, sauf s’ils absorbent activement de la matière et émettent de la lumière.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe de scientifiques dirigée par Emma Schwartzman a découvert trois trous noirs supermassifs dans trois galaxies différentes qui sont en train de fusionner en un seul système. Tous les trois absorbent de la matière et émettent des ondes radio, ce qui a permis aux astronomes de les observer clairement grâce à des radiotélescopes spéciaux à Hawaï et au Nouveau-Mexique.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois que des scientifiques observent trois trous noirs supermassifs en fusion simultanément, tous émettant des signaux radio. Cet événement rare aide les scientifiques à mieux comprendre comment les galaxies grandissent et comment les trous noirs interagissent lors de ces fusions complexes. Il donne aussi des indices sur les dernières étapes des collisions galactiques, qui se déroulent sur des milliards d’années.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont continuer à étudier ce système pour mieux comprendre la physique de ces fusions. Ils espèrent améliorer les modèles informatiques qui simulent la manière dont plusieurs trous noirs se rejoignent et influencent leurs galaxies.

**En une phrase** – Des scientifiques ont observé un événement rare où trois trous noirs supermassifs fusionnent, offrant de nouvelles connaissances sur la croissance des galaxies et le comportement des trous noirs.
articles.personality_title_es: Astrónomos observan la fusión de tres agujeros negros supermasivos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los agujeros negros supermasivos son objetos gigantes que se encuentran en el centro de las galaxias. A veces, cuando las galaxias chocan, sus agujeros negros pueden acercarse y unirse. Sin embargo, ver esto es muy raro porque estos eventos duran poco y los agujeros negros son difíciles de detectar a menos que estén activamente absorbiendo material y emitiendo luz.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo de científicos liderado por Emma Schwartzman descubrió tres agujeros negros supermasivos en tres galaxias diferentes que están fusionándose en un solo sistema. Los tres están activamente alimentándose y emitiendo ondas de radio, lo que ayudó a los astrónomos a observarlos claramente usando telescopios de radio especiales en Hawái y Nuevo México.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que los científicos ven tres agujeros negros supermasivos fusionándose a la vez, y todos emitiendo señales de radio. Observar este raro evento ayuda a los científicos a entender mejor cómo crecen las galaxias y cómo interactúan los agujeros negros durante estas fusiones complejas. También da pistas sobre las etapas finales de las colisiones galácticas, que ocurren durante miles de millones de años.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores seguirán estudiando este sistema para comprender mejor la física detrás de estas fusiones. Esperan usar estas observaciones para mejorar los modelos por computadora que simulan cómo se unen varios agujeros negros y afectan a sus galaxias.

**Una frase clave** – Científicos han observado un raro evento donde tres agujeros negros supermasivos se están fusionando, ofreciendo nuevas ideas sobre el crecimiento de galaxias y el comportamiento de los agujeros negros.
